citation.article-title: Halomonas maura sp. nov., a novel moderately halophilic, exopolysaccharide-producing bacterium.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Halomonas maura sp. nov.
Halomonas maura (mau'ra. L. adj. maurus northwest African)
Gram-negative rods, 6.9¬0.5-0.7 μm, occurring either singly or in pairs, occasionally as long filaments.
Cells are capsulated, non-motile and accumulate PHA.
Does not form endospores.
Colonies on MY medium are circular, convex, mucoid and cream-coloured; they are 2-3 mm in diameter after 24 h, but reach more than 5 mm in diameter and are considerably mucoid after 72 h at 32 °C.
Moderate halophile, capable of growth in salt concentrations of between 1 and 15% (w/v).
Optimum growth occurs in 7.5-10.0% (w/v) sea salts.
No growth occurs in the absence of salts.
Grows at temperatures between 10 and 40 °C (optimum growth at 32 °C) and at pH values between 6 and 9 (optimum growth at pH 7.2).
Chemoorganotrophic.
Metabolism is of the respiratory type, with oxygen as the terminal acceptor.
Capable of anaerobic growth in the presence of nitrate, but not in the presence of fumarate.
Catalase and oxidase are produced.
Does not produce acids from sugars.
Selenite is reduced and gluconate is oxidized.
H2S is produced from peptones and Tween 20 is hydrolysed.
Indole, methyl red and Voges-Proskauer are negative.
Aesculin, tyrosine, DNA, gelatin, casein, urea, lecithin and Tween 80 are not hydrolysed.
Blood is not haemolysed.
Phenylalanine deamination, growth on MY medium using the anaerobic Gas Pack System and growth on cetrimide agar are all negative.

The following compounds are used as sole carbon and energy sources: acetate, L-arabinose, D-galactose, D-glucose, D-gluconate, myo-inositol, DL-lactate, maltose, D-mannose, propionate, D-sorbitol and sucrose.
Formate, D-salicin and L-sorbose are not used.
The following compounds are used as sole carbon, nitrogen and energy sources: L-alanine, L-arginine, L-histidine, L-leucine, L-ornithine, L-serine and L-valine.
Cysteine and L-tryptophan are not used.

Susceptible to amoxicillin, ampicillin, cephalothin, cefoxitin, chloramphenicol, nalidixic acid, nitrofurantoin, polymixin, rifampicin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, but resistant to tetracycline and vibriostatic agent O/129.
Isolated from soil samples from a solar saltern at Asilah (Morocco).
DNA G­+C content is 62.2-64.1 mol% (Tm method).
The type strain is strain S-31T (=CECT 5298T=DSM 13445T).
The description of the type strain is the same as that of the species.
Additionally, phosphatase is produced.
Growth occurs on KCN and MacConkey agar.
Starch hydrolysis and ONPG are negative.
The following compounds are used as sole carbon and energy sources: citrate, ethanol, fumarate, D-fructose, glycerol, D-rhamnose and D-ribose; it does not use lactose or D-trehalose.
It is susceptible to gentamicin, penicillin, sulfonamide and tobramycin, but resistant to erythromycin.
Its DNA G­+C content is 64.1 mol% (Tm method).
It grows best in 9%(w/v) salts and has strict and specific requirements for Na+ and Mg2+.
The optimum NaCl concentration is 1.2 M; the optimum MgCl2⋄6H2O concentration is 0.2 M.
The major (up to 81%) fatty acids are 18:1ω7c, 16:1ω7c/2-OH i15:0 and 16:0.
This bacterium produces an exopolysaccharide, named EPS S-31, which is of potential industrial use as a viscosifier and emulsifier.
The physical and chemical properties of this polymer are described elsewhere (Bouchotroch et al., 2000).
Briefly, it is composed of the neutral sugars glucose, mannose and galactose at a ratio of 1:4:2.5.
The EPS aqueous solution (1%, w/v) attains a viscosity of 10.98 Pa s-1 at 4.5 Pa shear rate.
EPS S-31 is able to emulsify crude oil more efficiently than some chemical surfactants such as Triton X-100 and Span 60.
